er_text: I learned of Pouring Ribbons by an article a friend shared with me. The article talked about various cocktail bars across the US which featured "intelligently crafted" cocktails heavy on complex flavor and intrigue, and Pouring Ribbons was the cocktail bar featured for NYC.  Armed with this, a few of us came here for "research," of which I am a firm believer of verification testing of this sort of thing. After you climb up a flight of stairs, a hostess seats your party. The atmosphere is relaxing, maybe a little bit divey. The cocktails are indeed intriguing, enhancing your curiosity with their sliding scales for adventure and spirit. I stuck with bourbon-based cocktails for the evening, and I can vouch for where they fit on their sliding scales. They really need to pass out straws, because it's hard not to want to try everyone else's drinks. Our server was knowledgeable, humorous, and all-around fun with whom to chat. I give Pouring Ribbons a Blue Ribbon!

This is a cute, chill speakeasy bar in the east village. You'd have no idea when you walk past the door because its just bland and honestly that part of the street doesn't have that much going on. But once you get upstairs it's relaxed, and you're able to enjoy really well-made drinks with a great playlist all while still hearing each other and being able to talk. It's of course prohibition themed, as are lost speakeasys. We went on a Thursday night and it wasn't packed at all, which was so nice because we were looking for a relaxed environment to enjoy our night. The prices weren't bad for that kind of place I think it depends on what you get. In terms of selection their cocktail menu is great, it's definitely more of a cocktail bar than anything else since they do not serve beer on draft but still offer a few.

I was expecting more from this place after some friends suggested it. We came on a Friday night, really cold outside. They said at least a 30 minute wait, so we waited outside for a while. Eventually we were let in the door to wait at the bottom of the stairs, again for some time. The bouncer was pretty standoffish and made us feel like we should be thankful that he let us stand inside. Finally he let us in, and the place is half empty with many open tables, and for our group of 5 they just pulled 3 small round tables together for a somewhat awkward circle. It was kind of dark with no special lighting, not really any music playing, it felt almost like sitting in someone's dining room. The one good thing was the menu and drinks. We ordered:LADY PINK (Lady Grey-infused Tanqueray Gin, Lemon, Copper & Kings Immature Brandy, Italicus Rosolio di Bergamotto, Egg white, lavender, rose)DANCETERIA (Scarlet tea-infused absolut vodka, grapefruit, st-germain, aperol, cinnamon)WHEELS OF STEEL (Tanqueay Gin, toasted coconut infused plantation star rum, Giffard blue curaçao, pineapple, toasted coconut, mint sprig)  My friend also got a tequila drink I didn't catch the name of and my other friend some whiskey on the rocks. Overall the drinks were very unique in their own way, very carefully concocted. The Lady Pink wasn't too sweet and had a nice balance. Overall a nice place to have a chat with friends for a chill night, but it wasn't my favorite in terms of the ambiance and overall experience.

Thirsty IG account posted a few pictures of drinks from this bar. Both looked amazing so I highly made it here two years later to try it out. Neither was on the menu, but they were able to recreate one of the two because they had the ingredients. The two drinks I had were both delicious. The owner and hostess were also really nice and made sure we were happy with our drinks. Very attentive.

I went here on January 20, 2018. This one of my "backlogged" reviews. I got pretty drunk here which had less to do with the quality of the drinks and more to do with the fact that I didnt really like a single drink I got, so I just kept ordering more in the hopes that one would be satisfying.To be fair, I thought this place was fun, and their gimmick of ranking drinks from most familiar to most adventurous on one axis, and most refreshing to most spiritious on another axis was charming. I went with friends who also ordered drinks, so I got to try a wide variety. My biggest problem was this: with each drink one flavor always completely overwhelmed the others and nothing tasted like what you expected it to. The drinks were either too sweet or too boozy-tasting, which isnt something I like in a drink that isnt straight-up. Several drinks also call for cinnamon, which is mixed in at a ratio that completely overwhelms the other flavors. This place is also expensive, even by manhattan cocktail standards.I either tried or ordered the following drinks. I cant remember which is which from the pics, but I'm pretty sure this list is comprehensive:- SNO-CONE: FORDS GIN, LEMON, COCCHI AMERICANO, GIFFARD BLUE CURACAO, CINNAMON, PEYCHAUDS BITTERS (this one will f**k you up)- WHEELS OF STEEL: TANQUERAY GIN, PINEAPPLE, TOASTED COCONUT-INFUSED PLANTATION 3 STAR RUM, GIFFARD BLUE CURACAO  (this one came with a sprig of mint which made the drink tast like sweet toothpaste)- GEM SPA PIERRE FERRAND 1840 COGNAC, CAPATAZ ANDRES CREAM SHERRY, ANGOSTURA 7YR RUM, TEMPUS FUGIT CREME DE CACAO, WHOLE EGG, VANILLA  (this one tasted like a watered-down boozy chocolate egg cream...not my jam)- DINER MILK PUNCH MAKERÂ€™S MARK BOURBON, CLARIFIED CEREAL MILK, 146 PROOF TRINIDADIAN RUM, MARKET SPICE BLACK TEA, SPARKLING APPLE CIDER (this one tasted like straight up apple cider)- LADY PINK LADY GREY TEA-INFUSED TANQUERAY GIN, LEMON, COPPER & KINGS IMMATURE BRANDY, ITALICUS ROSOLIO DI BERGAMOTTO, EGG WHITE, LAVENDER & ROSE

Some of the best drinks I've ever had and a really cute place to go with friends. The bartenders are super sweet and if you tell them what you'd like they'll be happy to surprise you with something good! Always a great spot to go to when I'm back in my home city visiting!

I was tipped off to Pouring Ribbons by a bff. We're both i to craft cocktails and checked it out after a punk concert I was in the city for. Its on the outskirts of the east village but it felt like no-mans land. Without the line out the door, it would have been easy to miss. The doorman was nice as were the staff. I sat in the read center of the bar and ordered to drinks  both were good but not fantastic. I want to say their bar manager, though he could have just been an intelligent bartender, was explaining sugar levels within drinks to a cocktail n00b. He really knew his stuff and was enthusiastic in his explanation and knowledge. I might have been eves dropping a little. Anyhow- I got two drinks. The first was a blue foamy thing that was good but not mind blowing. The second was good but not memorable. I liked the vibe and would come back to try more of  the menu.

Fun, unique cocktail bar with some creative choices on the menu. It's pretty dark, which is typical of bars in this area -- so plan on needing to lean in a little to talk to and see your drinking companion(s).

The presentation of the drinks takes the cake on this one. I've not see such to do about a cocktail as I have here. They are really experiences. When coming with the group it is always just as exciting to have my own drink as to see what others have ordered. The bar staff is friendly and takes good humor in their work. The menu changes so that each time I find myself here I get to explore a new land of flavor. Highly recommend this spot ideal for dates!

Hidden gem on the lowers east side. Amazing cocktail menu and service. Cool vibe and ambiance to boot. Had the Bel Air and the Radio Rebelde...fantastic! Guy was awesome!! We will return on our next trip to NYC.

Just fantastic. I cannot recommend Pouring Ribbons enough. Firstly it's just the vibe you want if you're looking for a snazzy bar with high quality drinks, excellent service and an atmosphere conducive to a laid back evening with a dash of class. The drinks were delicious and are in fact the focal point of this establishment. The servers are very familiar with the drinks so they can actually help you decide what you're in the mood for. If your are coming here, I'd say know what liquor you like and don't because the menu can be overwhelming for a novice.  We started with the Salvador Dali and Zaha Hadid and we loved it! I recommend highly.  We invested in the sopressata too and also liked it, tho let's be real, it's expensive :). Still all around 5 stars for the experience and will absolutely be coming back.

Excellent cocktails . Excellent service . Nothing bad to say about this . There is a bit of a wait time outside before getting in however it's worth the wait .Very unique cocktails a relax atmosphere with great music. A must go to cocktail bar

Came here for drinks for a cute Friday date and this is such a great spot. They have great layout that doesn't make it feel over crowded without a bit of intimacy. Their drinks are good and fairly priced. Their service is awesome.

Came here on a mediocre first date a while ago. Thankfully, the drinks weren't mediocre.At 8 pm on a Sunday, it was pretty loud, largely because there was a private party happening around the bar. An older crowd. Service was reasonably prompt given the rush. Ambiance is decent.The menu has a grid of spiritous vs refreshing and adventurous vs comforting mapping their drinks. I don't think it's actually useful, though it may give you some confidence. Just look for ingredients that interest you. My date and I each had two and none were disappointing. Maybe I'm remembering it too fondly, but I would put it on par with Death and Co, Bar Goto, etc. Worth the $15 price tag for me.My visit was of the "crossing this off the list" variety but I did enjoy myself and it deserves a revisit.

Ask for Josh to make your drink.A stairway with teal painted walls, leads you to one of the better cocktail bars in NYC. An older crowd awaits, no teeny boppers here. Relax and enjoy your night! The menu filled with cocktails galore includes a map showing the various cocktails. From sweet to bitter and adventurous, the map is key to finding your favorite cocktail. I opted for Just Like Heaven (14) and fell in love with the smell of the torched thyme and the sweet but rustic taste. It's surely different and not what I had expected but definitely really good. Can't wait to try other cocktails on their menu.

The cocktails are $16 and come in small glasses, so they're pretty pricey. The Lady Pink was delicious, but some of their other drinks like Throwing Shade were way too smoky for my taste. I appreciated how they keep it spacious inside and not crowded at all like other bars, but the music was so loud that my throat was hoarse from screaming to talk to my friends all night.

Pouring Ribbons in the East Village/Alphabet City kind of places are pretty fun. It is definitely one of those older people crowd kind of places, but man are the drinks are strong and delicious. MENU: I would say that every drink I tried of our group of friends was mighty tasty. They have a nifty little chart on the menu stating the taste, i.e. how adventurous versus comfroting the drink can be. There is something for everybody's taste! That speakeasy type place is always fun to visit in New York and I highly recommend spending a night out in the town around this side of Manhattan!
MEAN MEAN MEAN STAFF! Not nice or fun. So pretentious. Rude, very rude. Bad service. Might come back but probably won't.

Speakeasy cocktail bars are not a new concept in the city but this one stands out thanks to a no-fuss door policy - no fuss vibes period -  a variety of good, yummy cocktails ($15+), good service, quiet ambiance, and... SPACE. You can come here with a large group (you might have to wait) but the space might have been the biggest speakeasy bar I've ever seen and believe me that was a plus. The menu has different sections and creative names and sadly I don't remember any of the names- they have numbers in which you can use to order.  My friend ordered one neon blue drink that was topped off with sprays (from a perfume bottle) of lavender absinthe.  Many drinks have a theatrical component  - i.e. my husband ordered a smokey Old Fashioned type drink which had some like of tea smoked in it.  He and the other guy we were with ordered traditional Old Fashion type drinks which were boozy and spice-y (like with cloves and such- spiced). I had a champagne cocktail with lemon and honey which was nicely not too sweet, refreshing and fizzy.  They also all the nice glassware, ice and adorn decor to all drinks.   Service is attentive but relaxed and the bouncer was tolerable. Highly recommend if in this quiet part of town.
By far one of the best places I've been too. The drinks are great and the scenery was pleasant. The waiter was very gracious and well verse on there drinks. Kudos guys keep up the great work.

One of my favorite cocktail bars in the city. The drinks are all on a scale so you can go more/less adventurous and more/less spiritous. The cocktails are about $15 but they're surprising, delicious, and fun. It's really all about the presentation of the drinks here.I don't think I've ever seen more than 5 people here when I go, so it's always quiet. Maybe it's just my timing, but I like a quiet bar so I won't complain. Staff are always very friendly!

Had this recommended by a friend, and I couldn't agree more with her suggestion. Steven was phenomenal, patiently explaining all of the drinks and ingredients to us and giving us samples of several other cocktails we were curious about. Despite the complex and phenomenal drinks available, not at all a snooty place.

Loved this spot! The bartenders were super friendly dispite how packed it was. Also the drinks were really tasty and well crafted. I haven't been to a bar before with such creative options. I would definitely love to come back next time I'm in NYC!

Ugh - this place will charm you with its location, vibe, and the artsy cocktail list.But the cocktails themselves? Unbalanced and just not fit for human consumption. These are cocktails that taste like paint thinner going down and guarantee that you'll feel crappy later.My beau and I went last night, with the intention of having a few rounds after a show nearby. Instead, we finished our drinks (Richard Serra and Ortega) with chagrin - honestly, we should have just settled up and left them there - and then moved along to the SUPERB Amor y Amargo nearby. Don't waste your time here. This nabe is cocktail Mecca and there are wayyyyy better options close at hand.

Great upstairs spot that has a new theme each season according to a buddy. They had a Cuban theme when I visited a week ago and had a Cuban style drink menu with Cuban artwork on the walls. If you have ever been to Catalina Island, this place reminded me of that. Perhaps it was their seasonal Cuban theme, but had an Island vibe with it being a little secluded and upstairs. We had an attentive server who provided recommendations and the drinks were strong and tasted great. They give you a post card with your tab so make sure to write it and send it to a loved one!

This bar is so much fun! It is one of the first bars I went to when I moved to the city! The drinks are so elaborate and complex - I love it! And they all have fun, thought our names! Try all the cocktails, they are all so good! The drinks totally suit the atmosphere, kind of an antique feel. Totally a great date spot!

Had the most lovely time there yesterday!! I guess because it's too Far East, it doesn't get as crowded during the wk nights- which is fantastic. You can actually hear what you are talking about.I'm a gin lover but was not sure about the mixed drinks menu- they have ~18 different kinds plus beer and wine- so good selection of drinks.The server was so nice: she recommended drinks and told me if I hated it she would replace it for me so I can enjoy my time there. Ended up loving all of them! Especially the gin with Greek yogurt ( if you are like me who loves the refreshing taste of cucumber g&t, don't worry about this drink being creamy, it's perfect with the coconut hint). The gin with aloe wasn't bad either but not as good as this.Will def come back!

The entrance looks like a normal door to go in any east village apartment old building, but there is a tag with the name on it..you go up the stairs and there you are in a cozy big wooden room with tables, definitely more space than other famous speak easy cocktail bars..Cocktsils are very well balanced with a sophisticated combination of ingredients and flavors. They have a map on their menu that locates your cocktail based on the alcohol content, the refreshing action, and other two characteristics, pretty cool thing..I had 3 differnet last night, all very interesting. The presentstion of their drinks is also beautiful.

Loved coming here as a Friday night late night drink spot. The servers are super helpful and friendly in helping you choose a drink from their VERY well thought out menu. Essentially all of their house made drinks are placed on a grid, helping you choose between the strength of flavor of your drink, to the type of liquor. All beverages are themed, which definitely provides a fun, quirky touch to the venue. For a weekend spot, the bar itself wasn't too packed and there was plenty of space / it wasn't too loud to catch up with a friend. The entrance to the bar is slightly hidden, giving the bar an overall speakeasy-like feel. For me and my more adventurous friends, would definitely recommend if you're looking for a cool, not too crowded spot in the LES.

Unique drinks, cool vibes. I came to the right place.Pouring Ribbons is a chill cocktail bar with a speakeasy vibe. The place isn't too difficult to find, since you'll find a bouncer at the door followed by a group of people waiting to get in. It wasn't hard to get in either. My friend and I got in with ease after just telling the bouncer there was two of us. The atmosphere was chill with dimmed lighting. We sat at the bar, but if bar seating is not for you, there's a bunch of couches and tables with stools. I can see it being a great place to come with a group of friends.The drink menu was extensive too. My friend and I actually had a hard time ordering because there were so many choices. Not only cocktail choices, but whiskey and other mix drinks as well. I ordered the punch cocktail which was very unique and flavorful. My friend got one with pineapple-a more tropical drink-and didn't enjoy it as much. Mine was strong too, which made it really worth the $15.If you're ever in the area or looking for a cool place to chill with friends, check this spot out.

The bar is up a set of stairs and once you enter, it's got a library feel to it, with a lot of wood and dark greens. The cocktails are very good and the last time I was there, our waitress was very attentive.My friends and I all enjoyed the cocktails we had and they were very creative. You could come on a date or with a small group of friends here and enjoy your evening with some great cocktails. I would definitely recommend coming here if you enjoy well made cocktails and a quiet ambiance.

The problem with this location is not the drinks but the letdown of it not being a Cuban speakeasy. The drinks were very good, but the ambiance was not Cuban at all. How are you going to sell Cuban drinks to some hip-hop music? Maybe I am a purist, but that's how the establishment is advertised. Also, the place sounded more like a crowded bar than a speakeasy. If you want drinks but don't care for the place not being a Cuban speakeasy, then yea sure go ahead. But yea that's why the place gets 3 stars from me

We wanted to find a fun and new place to get cocktails in our neighborhood. Most of the lists that I have looked over have this place near the top.It's a tiny little door which could be hard for some to find, but the name is written on the door. If it wasn't for the bouncer outside, we might've just walked right by it. When we were let in, we couldn't help but love the music and the all around vibe of the bar. I felt like I was back in the 60's even though I've never visited. I ordered a Ramos gin fizz which was made well and tasted great.I really enjoyed being at this bar and it's definitely a place we will return to when we need cocktails before dinner.

My review is about two months overdue but I still want to share my two cents.  The menu is presented as a 2D graph illustrating how refreshing vs. spirituous each drink is, and how comforting vs. adventurous.  A clever idea (which I've seen copied on the West Coast), but I think it's mostly intended for customers with limited knowledge of craft cocktails.  I first ordered the Ambrosial Sin (lapsang souchong infused rum, scotch, mole bitters) - a tasty take on an old fashioned but not that adventurous as I've seen those ingredients combined many times before.  The most unique feature was actually the bamboo koozie around the glass that awesomely prevented by hand from getting cold!After my first drink, I upped my standards for adventure and asked the bartender about My Dear Unfortunate Successor, which listed milk as one of the ingredients.  I liked all the other ingredients but was hesitant about the milk and she told me the milk was subtle so I went ahead and ordered it.  Well boy was I fooled - the milk flavor was so prominent I did not enjoy the drink at all and only finished it after it had been sufficiently diluted by melting ice.  Oh well, that's the risk I took when I decided to order it so that's on me.  But this is what really irritated me: When the bartender came by asking how our drinks were and I was like, "Uhh, it's really milky..."  her response was,  "Oh, well I don't think so" and walks away!  Do you think at $15 a drink you could care slightly more whether your customer likes the drink?!  At any other cocktail bar there would have been more discussion, and some bartenders might even whisk away the drink and make a new one!   Moreover, when my friend asked her about a mezcal behind the bar she was completely not engaged and said she couldn't make him a drink with it.  All in all, service was bad and drinks were fine.  Maybe there's a reason this place was mostly empty on the Saturday night we visited.  The experiences I had at Amor y Amargo and Death & Co were infinitely better.  Next time I return to NYC, I doubt I'll hit up Pouring Ribbons again.
Wow incredible tasty drinks with a knowledgeable wait staff that knows the drinks and guides you to the perfect drink for

I'd like to take a moment to rave about Pouring Ribbons. First, I liked that everything from the décor to the menus to the presentation of the drinks to the drinks themselves are influenced by the "along the silk road" concept. You'll find cocktails made with exotic ingredients such as makrut lime leaf poured out of opulently decorated teapots. Second, the drinks are wonderfully complex and delicious. I had the following:Gun Powder Empire (different rums, lime, sherry, house blackstrap rum, black pepper):  I found that the flavors in the blackstrap rum (licorice and molasses, especially the licorice) were most present in this drink, which is fine with me because blackstrap rum is awesome. Served over ice in an elegant mug.Stone Roses (bourbon, vermouth, orange-cherry shrub, root beer bitters): Hands down my favorite of the night. Distinct flavors that combine to create an incredibly tasty cocktail. The root beer bitters are very easily tasted here and add a lot of complexity to the drink. Love it. My boyfriend ordered the Painted Veil (Scottish Toffee Pu-Ehr Tea-Infused Beefeater Gin, sherry, amaro, baiju) and another drink I'm forgetting. Unfortunately, he wasn't quite as thrilled with his drinks as I was with mine-- hence the 4, not 5, stars.Nice touches include:-The [refreshing - spirituous - comforting - adventurous] matrix which helps patrons choose their preferred style of cocktail. However, I personally didn't find it to be very useful when picking a drink.-The spotlight on chartreuse. We are lovers of chartreuse, but only to the point where we are aware of the difference between the green and yellow varieties. PR has an entire page devoted to different kinds of the herbal liquor, lest you want to become a chartreuse scholar.-The thoughtful service. We were visiting PR on a busy Friday night, and although we were seated right away, the bar was apparently pretty backed up around the time we ordered our second drink as it took a long time for them to arrive. Patience apparently pays off here, as we were rewarded with shots of absolutely delicious whiskey for being the only group that didn't complain about the slow service. Just a note: Yelp says that Pouring Ribbons takes reservations, but they don't.

We arrived promptly at 6pm, opening time, on a Friday.  Greeted by security, my group and I were asked for our IDs, on his mic he signaled how many were coming up.  We walked up a flight of steps that led into a bar room with chairs and tables.  We sat near the main and only window of the venue.  The menu differs slightly from the online menu, however, because I wanted something that I saw online and not on the actual menu, they were kind enough to accommodate me with my request.  Cautionary Tale, Larceny & Old Lace, Vendetta Road, a classic Screw Driver, and Champagne were the drinks that circulated at our table.  Everybody enjoyed their own drink, so pending your taste buds and the mood you are in, go with it.  I doubt you will be let down.  The Cautionary Tale sorta reminded me of a French 75 with Tequila. However, I did end up ordering a champagne cocktail that bordered along the lines of a 75, however this one included a touch of lemon and a sugar cube.  It was soooo delish.I rarely, if ever, give credit to too many bartenders who refer to themselves as Mixologists, however Pouring Ribbons has exactly that.  These were perfectly created; the right about of alcohol, and mixers, neatly garnished with twists.  The atmosphere went from early evening daylight to comfortably dimly lit.  And not so dim you are falling asleep, but dim enough to still see the face of the person in front of you.  The music was a little to 80s for me.  And not that I don't appreciate the 80s, I wad looking for something a bit more up current and upbeat.  So were the couple we ran into as we were leaving.  Everybody enjoyed their cocktails, but it was the music that had us seeking new retreats.  But I will be back.

I came here with a date upon her spontaneous suggestion, after having a couple drinks at Mona's across the street. I was surprised when she said there was a cocktail bar right on that block, as I had lived in that area for 2 years and never heard of it. It's definitely well hidden, with a small door sandwiched between a local grocery store and Subway. As a result, the place had plenty of open seating when we arrived around midnight on a Saturday. I quickly found myself in love with the interior, a simple but beautiful room made largely of oak. The front of the room has a large seating area with a window overlooking the street. The waiter was very helpful and funny. I started with the Heart of Darkness while she got the Just Like Heaven. Mine was strong yet delicious, while hers was more refreshing. After we raved about the drinks to the waiter, he was awesome enough to get us free shots! Bill came out to roughly $16 per drink, so this place is certainly not cheap. The prices are commensurate with high end cocktail bars in the area. If you're looking for a hidden away, romantic bar with well crafted drinks, this is a must see. So glad my date introduced me to this place!

I'm sure I was influenced by the fact this joint is located in Alphabet City, but I really couldn't help thinking of Rent. The space is just so insanely cool. I couldn't stop looking around and looking up and down and out the window....it's just so New York. The cocktails were great too. There is a bit of a wait, but like the bouncer tells you, it's not that long. Worth it!

This is our go-to for great and innovative drinks in a cool setting. We also bring out of town guests. There can be quite a few tourists here sometimes but it doesn't really have a negative effect. Really great and carefully prepared drinks.

Interesting and strong cocktails.Walk up the staircases and you arrive at this far eastern inspired bar.The presentation of some of the drinks is very unique as they use tea cups and China to serve. It's a romantic place for a date, not too intimate, not too loud, just a place with good ambiance..

I'm a huge fan of this chill bar that serves classy cocktails. I love the bar menu, which begins with a chart that allows you to visualize and choose refreshing, comforting, spirituous, and adventurous cocktails on a two-by-two matrix :). My favorite cocktail is the I'm No Doctor as of now - I'm looking forward to trying new ones in the future!Pouring Ribbons has a nice open space that is dimly lit - great for groups.

This is my favorite cocktail bar in the city. I've tried drinks off of 3 of their seasonal menus and have enjoyed every single one of them. I love how they organize their menus with a chart in the front with descriptors like adventurous, spirituous, refreshing, etc. It really helps me decide what I want since their menu is pretty significant. And while I always get sad when the menu changes (because I find my favorites), I am never disappointed with the next version of the menu. There is always something new to try and I like that they keep me on my toes.Not only are the bartenders knowledgeable about the drinks on the menu, but also of the spirits behind the bar. We had a long discussion about gins and have even done a chartreuse tasting which was very interesting.The space is very comfortable and I like how it's not overly crowded. The location is kind of out of the way, but I feel like that is good because it means less people are in line because they need to really want to go.This is an awesome date spot or great place for friends to congregate and catch up. I would go at least once a week if I could afford it.

Happened upon PR during its once in a quarter on the last Monday of the month in that quarter special event. It's a tongue twister, calendar counting shake of the head, for sure. There doesn't seem to be much rhyme or reason to it, but it definitely drew a fun crowd. The theme was luau-pirate-70s from what I gathered. All the people who knew they were there for the occasion dressed up and the place had a little tiki-ish vibe, but I'm not certain the decor that helped give it said vibe is regularly island-themed. Beyond the anomaly of the decor and fashion of the crowd, the tiki-inspired drinks were a lovely surprise, as I don't think these are always available. A girlfriend got hers aflame, which is an exciting spark any evening libation, and I got one a tall drink of water (that was really some rum concoction), sporting crushed ice and a surfbort! I was straight grainin' on that wood, if you know what I'm sayin'. We both loved our punch drunk love libations enough to order another round. Our server kept an eye on us the entire time to make sure we didn't get swallowed up in the craziness of the night. While I can't comment on the average night at PR, I can definitely say, it's not to be missed if you're on the hunt for a cocktail in the East Village.

Let me just start off by saying I'm giving this place 3 stars because of the price..Anyways, drinks were amazing and very well thought out. 5 stars for presentation alone and taste is put of this world --- they are true mixologists over there. If you didn't know where the place was you would never find it. I walked right past the door at first! Kind of hidden..Walked in for the first time and it was a tiki bar theme with only speciality tiki/pirate theme drinks. Very cute and well executed.If it wasn't for the 15$ drinks I would definitely return.
Overall, great cocktail selection. This place has a classy, intimate vibe - great for catching up with friends or for a date. It isn't too loud or crowded. However, ambiance is not very "speak-easy."

Speakeasy style. Went on a Saturday night around midnight, wait was about 5 min outside.  Not obvious to find, but the doorman makes an excellent marker. So it's true, they make you wait but then there are plenty of empty tables inside.  Whatever, at least it's not crowded.  The bar is on the second floor, dark green library / card room style towards the front. The music was really loud and like...early 2000s pop / hip hop, which didn't really fit the menu of "moody authors," but maybe it's different other times of day. Service is great.  Drinks solid.  I had #18 "Real Horrorshow," a rum based drink with cachaca, earl grey, absinthe and clarified milk. My accomplice had brandy. The loukanika cured meat had some bite with the spicy fennel; good if you want something small to nosh on.  Our server threw in some complimentary wheat thins haha. Our cheese and loukanika portions were so dainty that I welcomed the carb-rich lunch snack. Not in love with the place because of the music, but maybe it takes a few tries / drinks. To be honest, I liked booker and dax so much more (good music, food, presentation).
Awesome custom cocktails.  Friendly service.  Comfortable atmosphere.  Had the Andy Warhol which came in a mini coke bottle. Delicious.  Lots of festive colorful flavorful options.

The music is always what I'd call bizarre-casual. Tonight it was a lot of Barry White (whom I adore) but otherwise way too much generic Disco, last time it was Johnny Cash (whom I adore) but otherwise way too much generic Disco. It has to be Pandora or Spotify, because the sound quality is really all over the place, sometimes worse than the radio, sometimes better than a compact disc, but whatever the theme of the evening, it's always unrelenting, and for me, when I'm looking for a break, it's not ideal.Other than the music, which prevents the atmosphere from ever being "chic" or "fab," which may or may not be a bad thing, this is a very comfortable place to lounge, and the drinks are consistently incredible, and the wait-staff are consistently very friendly.

I went in here with a friend as we were looking for some of the best cocktails in NYC. George did not disappoint. He asked what I wanted and I insisted vodka. He asked about a few other drinks and flavors I enjoy and came back with an amazingly presented whiskey (sorry I don't remember the name). Great drinks, great service. Highly recommend. Thanks George and sorry it took like 2 months to write the review.
My favorite bar in NYC! Cocktails are great, and it's such a civilized place. Music is good but not too loud and one can usually find a place to sit!

Delightful cocktail bar that has the allure of the speakeasy without the label. The semi-hidden entrance would be difficult to find...if there wasn't a comically serious bouncer guarding the door. In any case, that's more for show - he'll make it seem like this is some sort of exclusive venue, but chances are, you'll get right in. Came here on a Friday night around 8:30 and the place was maybe 60% full (filled up quite a bit as the night went on, as one would expect). 8:30 turned out to be a great time to go, because we were seated quickly (albeit next to a couple that decided Pouring Ribbons could be their own personal make out den). I appreciate the table service here - cocktail bars of this ilk aren't always that generous, so I very much appreciated our bubbly, down to earth waitress.The menu here can be described as an example of simple genius. Under each listed cocktail, there are two spectra on which the cocktail falls - comforting to adventurous, and refreshing to spirituous. I say simple genius, because any cocktail bar could do this. Sure, you could find this out anywhere with enough questions, but the fact that this is already laid out for you is a nice touch. If you're new to cocktails, this little guide is your friend. And even if you're a cocktail nut like me, knowing that a cocktail is on the adventurous side (okay okay, if you're a cocktail nut like me than you can probably figure out where a cocktail falls on that spectrum without assistance) can affirm your hope about a particular drink.\Now for the drinks: I tried the "Rags to Riches" (Fighting Cock Bourbon, Cardamaron, Vanilla, Root Beer Bitters) and the gin old fashioned. The Rags to Riches is definitely more on the comforting side - it's essentially a boozy root beer float. What could be better than that? It's simple, sweet but not sickly so, and will definitely put a smile on your face. The gin old fashioned isn't for the faint of heart. This baby is STRONG. But fantastic. One unique thing about Pouring Ribbons is its twists on the classics. I've only experienced an old fashioned with whiskey. But I actually got a little lesson in mixology while I was here - an old fashioned simply implies a preparation with sugar, bitters and orange. The rest can be improvised. So over the past few months, Pouring Ribbons has offered both a tequila and a gin old fashioned. Wouldn't have been able to stomach this drink with tequila, but I thoroughly enjoyed the gin version. If you're a big gin fan and prefer a spirit-forward cocktail other than a martini, go for this one.

Bestie & I stopped at Pouring Ribbons for an early evening drink this past Saturday.  Being that it's highly rated, I was very surprised to find the venue so empty!  With the help of our quirky & kind bartender, I chose a tequila based drink with charcoal-activated ingredients and a raspberry flavor.  Bestie went for a gin-based drink with a velvety citrus flavor.  Yes, both drinks were tasty... but not good enough for a second round.  The music & atmosphere were also a turn-off.  Glad I crossed it off my list, but no need to go back.

I very seldom visit bars that don't specialize in (craft) beer nowadays, and I seldom leave said bars thinking I want to come back. But I would come back to Pouring Ribbons any day and here's a few reasons why.Pouring Ribbons is another one of those faux-Speakeasy type bars that seem to be trending in NYC right now. It's hidden very inconspicuously on the second floor of an unsuspecting city corner and you wouldn't notice that it's there save for the formidable looking bouncer that's guarding the door with the "you shall not pass... unless you're of legal drinking age" look on his face.Despite being a trendy, classy joint, Pouring Ribbons was also overly accommodating. I was in NYC unexpectedly for the weekend after I learned that Misha T. was in town all the way from the Best Coast. This happened while I was grocery shopping at Mitsuwa in Edgewater, so I was kind of walking around in grocery shopping clothes. (comfortable clothes, clothes that would be denied entrance in most classy joints) I myself was walking around with a t-shirt, jeans and birkenstocks, while my friend was wearing a sports jersey. But the bartenders and the bouncer didn't care; hell they didn't even give me an awkward eye for being severely under-dressed while sitting on a fancy reclaimed vintage wooden stool sipping 15 dollar mixed drinks on a table by the window. Now that's my kind of joint.And of course, the drinks. The fancy menu they have here sorts drinks in four distinctive criteria: Comforting, Refreshing, Adventurous and Spirituous. Their menu also lists the active ingredients for each drink , but their little drink graph definitely helped me pick my poison of choice from their arsenal of delicious concoctions. I may have mentioned earlier that I don't frequent bars that specialize in mixed drinks, and that is mainly because my spirits of choice tend to be Scotch from the marvelous island of Islay. Pouring Ribbons has two amazing cocktails that they conjure up using Laphroaig Quarter Cask(!) -- If you're a Scotch lover, definitely try the "Bad Habit" and "Penicillin." It'll make a believer out of you as it did me.Overall, amazing drinks, great atmosphere, awesome service. I'll be coming back very very soon.

Finally managed to come here after a long time trying. The place is a little further out than I expected so be prepared to walk a little. It's a good size and would look nice in the dark. I came and got a couple of drinks - she's no lady and drop shot. The drinks are thoughtfully prepared and well designed, well mixed too. Yes they are pricy but I think I would rather pay the price for a good drink. The waitresses are helpful and give good recommendations too. I'll be back to try the others!

Wow! My boyfriend took me here and we both really liked it. Okay so to be honest, I was a little concerned as I looked up at the building. The entrance is unassuming and I think that's part of the charm. The cocktails are eclectic and diverse flavors that somehow blend perfectly together.  I also loved the playlist :) This is definitely a hidden treasure in Alphabet City!

I've only been here once so far but I think I love this place. I'm sure it gets mobbed on weekends, but on a Wednesday after midnight it was blessedly deserted- only two tables and two bars stools were occupied. The space is beautiful. Up a flight of stairs that shields you from the street, you come into low light, a beautiful arched window, intimate tables and cozy couches. Service was friendly, attentive, and helpful. I forget the name of the drink I ordered, but it tasted like it was made specifically with me in mind. Both sweet and spicy while also being balanced, it had some chipotle....syrup, I think, that made the whole thing just a little smoky. It was perfect, and came in a big ridiculous glass with an umbrella. The atmosphere was *begging* for some kind of jazz or funk, but unfortunately we were getting....well, things like Pharrell Williams's "Happy". If I can hear it at a supermarket, I'd rather not hear it at a speakeasy. Then they busted out with the Spice Girls "Wanna Be" and it was our cue to go. I couldn't tell if I was mortified or impressed, but I think it speaks to their fun personality that they played it. I mentioned I'm coming back, right?
2nd time here, Confirming how amazing this place is. The drinks are excellent and thw service is amazing  (thanks Britt for being awesome)

After a delicious birthday dinner we were seeking out some craft cocktails in the area. That's where this place delivered in spades. Don't remember our bartenders' names but they were awesome! Very knowledgeable and they described every flavor, every note with laser accuracy. Upstairs on the 2nd floor, kind of a speakeasy feel. A little empty for 8/9pm but we didn't mind. If you're in the neighborhood and seeking some grown up, expertly crafted cocktails, this is the place!
Really awesome atmosphere with fantastic cocktails. I went after work and got the jalapeño margarita; it was the best margarita ive ever had! Highly recommend for a nice drink with a few friends.

Love how it is tucked away! Service was quite slow on a Friday night so be warned. It's a perfect spot for a small group or a date night and the cocktails are definitely strong. Presentation is key and some of the drinks are put in teacups! Highly recommend it and they also have 4 categories of drinks and a grid filled with the different numbers of different drinks and based on how "refreshed" and "adventurous" etc. you want to be, you pick the number and match the drink on the menu. It's a bit pricey, but I would say it's standard for a nicer cocktail I suppose. Ambience was awesome.
Great cocktails, excellent menu, and nice ambience.
Very awkward to walk all the way to avenue b to find this placed closed for "menu revamp" in the middle of published business hours!!!  Never got to go in

Pouring Ribbons serves delicious, beautiful cocktails (for a whopping $14 per drink). When I went two weekends ago, I was with a group of 6 and we were worried about not being seated since it's a rather small lounge.  The bouncer was super nice to us and said they could make room for all of us upstairs and we were seated at high tables with stools. Later on, 2 more people joined us and when another large party left we were moved to their couches (much more comfortable.. their stool/table ratio is really odd)... I ordered the gimlet (except with vodka) which was absolutely delicious and the Moscow Mule, which was a bit too gingery for my taste. Water is automatically given to everyone and constantly refilled which is always nice. The waitresses were friendly but also pretty slow - It took us over 20 minutes to flag one down and get the check.I also came here just yesterday on a Monday night, and was pleased to see they had created a new Summer menu. I ordered a pina colada variation with chipotle, which had a great smoky taste and garnished with toasted coconut. The rum, chipotle, and coconut all tasted so good together and it was a nice switch-up from the original too-sweet colada. I also had a drink (the name escapes me) with vodka and watermelon, garnished with a flower shaped watermelon which was sweet but not too sweet. The drinks are honestly worth the $14.

I am a huge fan of unique cocktail bars and NYC has no short supply. It thrills me when I come across one that has actual personality and fantastic cocktails, like Pouring Ribbons.The bar itself has a gorgeous wooden interior that is more classic than contemporary. We chose to sit at the bar, close to the mixing action.  Round One:Bad Habit - Wild Turkey 101 Rye, Cantaloupe, Cynar, Egg White, Laphroaig Quarter Cask: This was my favorite of the four that we tried and I would return just for this drink. The Wild Turkey 101 Rye and Laphroaig Quarter Cask gave it a nice, strong punch while the cantaloupe and egg white kept it fruity and frothy. I truly felt like a lady-like tough girl sipping on this wonderful creation.She's No Lady - Linie Aquavit, Lemon, Hayman's Old Tom Gin, Lemongrass Syrup, Celery Bitters: This cocktail was incredibly refreshing and absolutely perfect for a hot summer day. I recommend this drink if you are not looking for a strong flavor of spirits.Round Two: East of Eden - Citadelle Gin, Lime, Laird's 7  1/2 Yr Apple Brandy, Orgeat, Granny Smith Apple: Another refreshing cocktail with pleasant apple notes from the brandy.Chartreuse Swizzle - Typically, it consists of Chartreuse (a French herbal liquor similar to Strega), falernum, pineapple juice and lime juice and garnished with nutmeg and a mint sprig: This delicious drink was served in a tall glass packed with shaved ice to keep the booze level steady throughout.The menu at Pouring Ribbons has enough variety to keep me coming back and their garnishes are fresh and beautiful. The mixologists behind the bar are very accessible and will even write the recipes you would like to know about on the backs of their post cards. We had a great discussion about Chartreuse with ours, it was great to learn about a liquor that is, to us, unfamiliar.  All in all a great experience.

Pouring ribbons is one of those places that you wont find unless you are looking for it. I almost missed the door!Pouring ribbons is a proper bar. With proper drinks. And proper everything. Will i come back? Yes!

Lovely New York style speakeasy! Nice staff, chic ambiance, creative cocktail selections and the very considerable (nerdy... but nerdy is new sexy) chart for each drink.I liked how they put all fresh cocktail ingredients in front of you at the bar line - olives, berries, oranges...  bright and refreshing. I tried Dark and Stormy - very delicious!However, I found, the major ingredient of cocktails at this place is ice, by both mass and volume. I am so curious if they rotate the menu in the winter....Will have to come back.

AhhhhhhhMAAAZINGGGGG Cocktails. Love love loved this place. The concept was awesome, the menu was a matrix of four choices adventurous, spirituous, comforting, refreshing and you choose a number.  I went with a mix of refreshing and adventurous and the cocktails were SO delicious some of the best i've had in the city.The feel was casual, dark, with couches and wood tables.  I will 100% be back here for some fancy drinks !!!

Very cool speakeasy! We were here on a Saturday night and ordered 2 drinks each for a party of 6. We were seated at a comfortable corner booth that was spacious enough for all of us. The service was great. One thing that's awesome about speakeasies is that the servers really know the drinks. They give great recommendations and know about how the drinks are made. The drinks were all quite delicious and not ridiculously strong. Between the 6 of us and the 2 drinks/person, we tried probably 8-10 drinks. I think there's only 1 or 2 restrooms, but I never found it a problem and didn't have to wait. The whole speakeasy is pretty dim but has several different types of seating- bar seating, sofa lounge areas, high stools at high tables, etc.We were definitely making a bit of a raucous towards the end of our time at Pouring Ribbons, but the servers were really cool about it. It is a bit out of the way from where we are, but I would love to come back again!

Walked over here one night after dinner and had a few drinks. The unassuming entrance is off Avenue B in Alphabet City. Look for the narrow green awning and green door that simply says POURING RIBBONS. Take a flight of stairs up and you're transported to another time. No pressure of hanging over a bar counter hoping the bartender will make eye contact. Make yourself comfortable at a table and a server will take care of you. A casual lounge atmosphere. Dimmed lights and a cozy place to chat and enjoy interesting cocktails.

I didn't know I loved cocktails before I came here. They're SO good. The menu also makes it super easy to look for cocktails that I'm in the mood for, rather than looking at a list. Drinks range from adventurous to spirituous to comforting to refreshing and everything in between. The vibe is so chill and private, the staff knows their shit, they're pros. I also love that a lot of women work here...i can chill by myself or with girlfriends without worrying about sleazy people.It's a perfect place to come solo, or on a date, or with friends. I wouldn't change a thing.
Great speakeasy bar in the E Village. Low key not pretentious off the beaten path with great music & drinks!

A little bit hidden but worth the search. The drinks were strong and interesting. The details in the seasonal menu were nice. The interior was simple but the use of color and art deco lighting gave it such a nice vibe. I ordered the "Way of the Warrior" the rum was a bit too strong for my tastes so I would probably order something different next time. Another plus is that the servers know a lot about each drink. Over all I think it would be a fun place to bring someone for a date. :)

I came here for the first time this past weekend and had no idea what to expect. When we got there, there wasn't a line outside, but we had to wait a little bit before we were allowed inside. This place definitely has a speak-easy feel and loungy vibe so they try to limit the number of people allowed inside. I was definitely in a bit of an adventurous mood and decided it was about time I stepped out of my comfort zone full of gin and tonics with a splash of lime. Anyone who knows me know that I am one of the worst person at making unimportant decisions (aka what to order on a menu) and usually just panic and get something I don't like. WELL I was determined that today was not going to be that day. They have this grid graph thing that you can pinpoint your exact mood on to determine the most appropriate drink for you! How neat is that? (that's pretty neat) It ranged from spirituous to refreshing, and comforting to adventurous. I think they should try to incorporate #sassy into that grid somehow as that tends to describe my exact feelings, but I guess their current one will work. I guess I was feeling more on the "refreshing" and "comforting" side at the time as I ended up getting the Larceny and Old Lace cocktail for $14. It was super refreshing and also had a bit of comfort to it (wow funny how that works . . . well done Pouring Ribbons). It was a tequila, hibiscus and raspberry drink which is not something I would typically order but hey that grid thing is pretty neat so happy for me that it worked out I guess! Brian (being the manly man he is) ended up getting some sort of dark hard alcohol without any ice type of thing aka my worst nightmare (but he liked it so happy for him too I guess). The vibe is very loungy and there were a lot of dates. I saw one big group, but besides that it was definitely more one-on-one dates. Oh wow there was also a couple getting a bit down and dirty on the couch next to us so happy for them too I guess!This is an awesome date spot all you gents out there. I guess $14 is a bit steep for a cocktail, but for a place like this I feel that that's the standard at this point slash sorry boyz.

Definitely a unique find in this area of the city. The only way the ambiance can be explained is "interesting". You feel like you're in New York but strangely outside of it. Great vibes and great people that enjoy a great cocktail.This place clearly has some of the best cocktails in this part of town. You might have a little trouble finding it but it'll be worth it.Try "No Crying In Baseball" you even get a 'free' baseball card :0

What a great place to grab a drink on a Friday night. While at first I was skeptical since this was so far from where my friends and I were hanging out, I found this bar to be completely relaxing, comfortable, and actually a great place to hang out and have an actual conversation!No BOOM BOOM BOOM music playing in the background, deafening me. No overpriced tasteless drinks. While each cocktail is $15, I found this to be completely worth the price, as each drink was unique and my friends found them to taste delicious.There's no rush of people pushing each other to get a drink, everyone gets to be seated and servers take our orders.Would definitely come again, the service was good, the drinks were good.

Would recommend the "Larceny & Old Lace" and the "Vendetta Road" . Great place for an escape from the typical drink. It's an experience for certain . Girls Night, Guys Night , Date Night or Solo Dolo .

This is a hole i the wall, literally... I had a little difficulty finding this place, however, once inside, it's a cute place.  They specialize in cocktails, and their bar staff is very  knowledgable.  Although I don't get out to this area very often, I recommend it, and would go back.

Had an interesting night here: some strong pros and strong cons. Pros: cocktails were great, our waitress was super friendly and helpful, the ambiance was great, and they let you bring in cake/cupcakes without charging a ridiculous "plating fee"Cons: got berated by the hostess for no reason. We initially showed up as a small group--no reservation--and they seated us quickly. So far so good. There were a few other friends who had said they might stop by, but we left it open ended. When some of these friends showed  up later, the hostess got flustered and starting yelling at me about needing to notify her in advance if anyone else was planning to join. A) No need to flip out regardless of what's going on B) I didn't know I needed to notify her, since we weren't working with a reservation, C) it's 2016...people don't provide air tight commitments to things unless they are specifically asked to do so, and this didn't seem like one of those situations. D) it wasn't that crowded at the time--shouldn't they be happy with more patrons? When I told her I didn't know that these friends were planning show up, she said, "you have a phone right? Tell them to text you". She was so hostile that several people from our group just left and went to the bar across the street. In conclusion, if you know exactly how many people will be part of your group, this is a wonderful place to get a cocktail. If you're trying to coordinate a larger meetup, be careful.

Pouring Ribbons is a cozy speakeasy with a sexy, intimate vibe. They keep a limit on how many patrons they host at a time, so there may be a short wait outside until the doorman gives you the ok to walk up the stairs into this dimly lit hideaway. A pretty good choice for date night if you want to impress someone. With plenty of quiet corners, it's a change of scenery from the typical loud and overcrowded East Village bar. Their cocktails are defined on scales of Refreshing to Spirituous, and Comforting to Adventurous. They even have a nifty chart in their menu to help you identify where certain drinks stand! I recommend the Wings of Desire. If only the "mixologist" serving us that night at the bar wasn't so pretentious and rude. She really killed it for us.

Finally got to check out this place. It's a big space with many tables. Came on a Saturday night and didn't wait for a table for 5. Cocktail menu is like no other. Definitely a twist with Indian and Asian influenced ingredients. Strong but well balanced.

Bit out of the way, but still a really nice place!Not much problem getting in for us; just asked if there was available space. Later two guys joined us, though, and it was a bit more problematic - they were barely let in! And our waitress complained about having people join us.Speaking of which, she was suuper annoying/mean in general, and didn't let us move to a free table when we first arrived (she told us, "this is not the type of place where you can just go to a table"..)Once we got a new waitress, though, things changed - she even changed my drink (tried Acquavit & Cynar drink - hated it) to a tried and true vodka gimlet. Also tried a gin & lime and that was good too.Ah, and the bar also had very cool menu with locations, where you could locate your perfect drink based on how "adventurous" or "refreshing" you wanted to be! They give you a postcard with the cheque too :)
Drinks are great but watch out for the blonde hostess, for you are in for a very rude sarcastic encounter. Besides that, great laid-back visual atmosphere.
The drink is so good ! Highly recommended!!! Love this bar! Staffs are nice! Owner is nice too. The bartender George makes the best drink. Will come back soon !

As someone who is still deeply entrenched in the college bar scene, where shots are cheap and encouraged to be taken in loud, racuous groups, this place was a definite change of scenery. The name is written in yellow on a brightly lit green background, and looked like it could have been a small bodega. What awaits upstairs was unexpected. I've never tried out any other speakeasy's for drinking (I've been to one other for dinner), so I didn't know that inquisitive bouncers were standard. I was just confused as to why the bouncer cared so much about whether me and my roommate were going to meet anyone upstairs. There was a group in front of us that was told to come back in 20 minutes because there was no room. But they waited, and their patience was rewarded within 5 minutes. I guess this place isn't a big fan of a long line to get in--playing the part of a bootlegging joint, maybe. My roommate and I were allowed in after being told that there might only be one seat, and that there was a chance we would both have to stand. Of course that was fine, because I didn't even know that there were bars where you didn't expect to be standing...We walked up the carpeted steps and entered the 1920s. The people were dressed nicely, albeit casually, and the bartenders on that night were both women wearing cute, hipster-chic outfits complete with suspenders. There was a "garnish" area--very fancy. The menu is printed on beautiful paper, and there is a scale listed under each cocktail that goes from Comforting to Adventurous, and Refreshing to Spirituous. I only tried one drink--the airmail (sparkling wine, honey, some other good stuff), and it was delicious. My roommate opted for the gimlet, which was great. I tried a couple of our other friends' drinks as well, and they were all very good. The prices, which are not printed on the menu, are not particularly low, but wouldn't break the bank if you're just casually drinking and not looking to get wasted. There's something that seems inherently blasphemous with chugging well-made cocktails, anyway... These drinks were works of art, and the candle-lit space gave the impression that you would never, ever hear anyone shouting for tequila shots here. I felt classy and upscale, and it was annoying when the waiters/waitresses kept telling us we HAD to sit down because it felt restricting, but I respected that there was a certain ambience to uphold. Pouring Ribbons seems like a beautiful spot for a date, too. I would definitely come back.

This place is severely understaffed. Prepare to wait upwards for an hour before drinking anything. Drinks, though sound good, were underwhelming.0/10Would not drink again.Seriously, there are way better cocktails in the area. Go to Mace.

I was in New York for a couple of days and had asked friends for chill bars with good cocktails and friendly bartenders-three of them mentioned Pouring Ribbons...Great place, fun cocktails, and a whole page of Chartreuse selections-I would definitely recommend!

I have never been to a speakeasy so this is my first time. The only thing is I had to wait at the door, in the cold when it was pretty empty upstairs. But my annoyance was gone once I stepped inside the decorated space. I loved the interior design and how the seats are designed and placed. The menu is cute. I didn't know what I want so when I told the waiter I want something sweet, he said you gotta give me more information (coldly). So being someone who doesn't drink a lot, I was like hummm and suddenly the waiter goes I KNOW WHAT TO GET YOU and he went away. I personally trusted him being that I have heard good things about the place. The only thing is when it came, he didn't tell me what it was. I was expecting him to be like this is blah blah blah. I didn't ask either but it was pretty spot on as to what I like and it is very light ;) I like how they don't rush you and that it has a relaxing vibe. I hate to walk between crowds at bars.I can see myself coming back but definitely want to try more speakeasys!

Went to this place and Booker and Dax back to backService was ok, Drinks were a bit better than B&D and the menu had 2-3x more choices which I liked.However, drinks were not that impressive and for $14 each they are pretty small

Loved this old school bar in the Lower East Side. This neighborhood has great places to eat and drink and Pouring Ribbons deserves a spot on the roster. It feels like a speak easy. Our bartender was so gracious in his recommendations.  I was frightened of most of the house cocktails since they seemed very serious. I settled on the Montgomery Burns and it was eggscellennt!Next time I'm up for the chartreuse...now that I know the staff wouldn't steer me wrong.
This is pretty classy place for avenue b.  Or maybe that's just what ave b is like these days.  Fancy well made cocktails, people sitting at tables like they're civilized or something.

So bummed that I'll be moving out of this neighborhood because Pouring Ribbons is seriously one of the best.  Great cocktails are a given, but it's the chill and mature environment/crowd that really sets this place apart.  They don't allow patrons to stand at the bar, making for a much more relaxed experience than other great cocktail bars in the city.  Definitely worth the trek to Ave B!

Love the setup - there is a bit of everything here, from tables by the window to comfy couches to talk bar tables and stools. Your pick, but you sure will find good space to park yourself and enjoy their well-crafted cocktails. They were not very busy early in the evening, which works perfectly for those of us with odd working hours (or if you manage to escape work early to grab a drink!). Hostess was a darling, and super helpful with all drinks discussions and selections.Now, to the drinks. I had to try Pisco, of course. The Colonial Affair was very citrusy as I expected, but also much lighter than traditional Pisco cocktails. May it was an addition of Lillet Rose... It was delightful no less. If you like refreshing and light cocktails, definitely give it a try. My second choice, Yellow King, was fantastic. Mezcal, gin, campari, yellow pepper and thyme syrup - perfect. That I will most definitely order again.Special mention goes to their homemade hummus, served with truly artisanal, delightful crackers - yum! Great snack to go with drinks.Great lounge, spectacular cocktails.

No contest: this is the best place I have ever been for cocktails. We visited during the Route 66 menu (highlights: Night at the Wigwam, Complements of Mr. Harvey, Best Thing Since Sliced Bread, and No Crying in Baseball) on a Monday night. There was lots of space at the bar, so that's where we asked to be seated. The menu has this great grid system for explaining whether a drink is refreshing or boozy, and traditional or adventurous, which I felt made ordering our first drinks much easier. Once our bartender, George, realised that we were interested in cocktails, he let us talk his ear off (and returned the favour) for hours. He was great at making recommendations based on what we found interesting (we're frustrating because we like everything and never narrow things down), gave us the lowdown on the best cocktail spots in Manhattan, and told us all about the Pouring Ribbons 'program' - what they're trying to accomplish there, which is just pushing the limits on what you think drinks can be. I'm positive that they'd make an outstanding whatever-you'd-like-to-drink, but you should let them test your boundaries. He also walked us through several of the cocktails we didn't have and gave us a taste of some of the ingredients they've developed or are working on. Because the menu changes, if you have a drink you really like you can ask them to write it down on a postcard for you so that you can make it at home or they can reconstruct it for you if you come back after the menu changes. They keep loads of ingredients for off-menu drinks on-hand, so it's likely they can accommodate. Also the only place I've ever seen with vintage Chartreuse, including some that sells for $100 a half-ounce and is 70 years old. They said that it's one of only two bottles they know of. Given the it the Canadian dollar has taken recently, this was a little tough on the pocket book, but worth it. I so hope we'll be back sooner than later.

The chairs/stools at the large tables were extremely uncomfortable, they left us wanting to finish our drinks quickly and leave. Maybe that is their plan?  I had the Misfortune of Virtues cocktail, described to me to be similar to a French 75.  It was very heavy light lemon but otherwise just ok. Nothing special. This place has a lot of potential. Bathrooms were messy and it wasn't even that busy, so I don't know how they let them reach that point.

Hey bartender! Pour those delicious ribbons of sweet, sweet liquor straight into my greedy mouth, puhhleasseee ...The moment I climbed up the stairs past the cute little teal painted door, I fell in love with this place. Unpretentious decor, spacious tables, friendly waitstaff, light snacks, appropriately dim lighting, and music at a tolerable level, all set the ambience just right for a small get together with fellow cocktail enthusiasts on a sleepy Sunday evening.The waitress was fantastic at handling our party, and also kind enough to let me order off menu (I got the deliciously complex "Lust for Life" which is a throwback to PR's original menu, no longer on the seasonal rap sheet, but available upon request) and settled nicely into a buzz shortly thereafter.Another fun novelty of the menu is that you can simply order by number along their cocktail profile grid (adventurous, spirited, refreshing, etc etc) if you want to be a little more wild. Of course, you can easily reference the drinks by their ingredients as well, but where's the fun in that?If you've never been, I suggest ordering one house specialty, and then trying a more traditional drink (think negroni, martini, old fashioned, aviation, if you catch my drift). This is a surefire way to get the best of both worlds - the creativity and novelty of a fun/weird/unexpected drink, and the boozy dependability of a classic.I'll definitely return, well worth a trip on the L train!
Update: Been here twice now and solidified a minimum 4 star rating; the service is great (I've been fortunate to go twice when it wasn't packed) and the drinks are tasty. Will go back again soon.
great cocktail bar in Alphabet City. Up there with Wayland on Ave C.they specialize in Chartreus, which I did not try, but maybe next time.

Aside from great cocktails, the ambiance of this place just works. A lot of other speakeasy style cocktail bars can be so dark you can't even see who you're with, or you squashed at a table or seat at the bar and basically breathing down everyone's necks. This place had both dimly lit lighting that aired on the side of inviting and able to see your companions, as well as spacious enough that you felt comfortable the whole time. Note though: the bar stools could be a bit more comfy. After two cocktails I felt like I had been out on my road bike for several laps around central park. If I had to choose again, I would have opted for a table, out of sheer butt comfort. All that being said...I really liked my two drinks. Best Thing Since Sliced bread was a winner. It reminded me of the butternut old fashioned from J Bird (RIP), that I loved so much. Great peanut flavor on the front end and a nice full bodied bourbon to round it out. Our bartender was great. When my friend didn't love one of her cocktails he actually just picked it up on the tab. He wanted us to be happy about what we got so he took it upon himself to make sure we were happy. I would definitely recommend coming here if you enjoy carefully crafted libations. Oh and the music was on point. Really good mix of today's hits mixed with hip hop favs like Justin Timberlake, Jay-Z, Biggie, Drake, Rihanna, and Missy Elliott. Deal Seeking Diva tip: Pick up your motel key on Sunday or Mondays and try each of Route 66 cocktails before they change the menu in April (doesn't have to be in one visit), and you'll receive an Old Fashioned travel kit. Will have to get on this myself!
Hands down, most creative, exquisitely crafted and informed staff of any of the stellar cocktail bars in NYC. Spent NYE there this year, and everyone we brought was very pleased.

Great cocktails, youthful but sophisticated vibe, not overly pretentious, knowledgable and decent service, extensive cocktail menu with diverse options, ranked in the menu on two scales- spirituous to refreshing and adventurous to comforting-- which is a pretty fun an funky idea-- and all including ingredients you've never heard of (even if you're well versed in the libation arena).  We also enjoyed some tasty nuts.Arrived around 10 last night (Saturday), party of three, seated immediately at a table big enough for 5-6, and weren't rushed out after two rounds of drinks. Looking forward to returning and tasting some more magical cocktails. On the way out around 12, there was a line of about 7-10 people but the inside wasn't at capacity.  Get there a bit earlier to avoid the line.

This place takes itself so seriously that it becomes nothing more than the butt of bad joke. If you want to be welcomed by an inviting host/ess, you want to enjoy an intimate setting and/or the ambience of a "speakeasy," and you want a great mixologist to make you $15 cocktails that are worth every dollar, try Raines Law Room or Dear Irving (or, Hell, any number of other places that seek to offer all of the above, rather than trying to create a false sense of exclusivity). But do not make the mistake of coming here, thinking you're getting anything more than a laughably pretentious hostess who makes guests/patrons wait outside unnecessarily before meeting their party, which in our case was already inside, and a half-empty bar serving outrageously overpriced cocktails. When not using her almighty walkie-talkie to radio the doorman to turn would-be patrons away or make in-comers wait unnecessarily, she made herself thoroughly useful by fluttering around the room refilling bottomless glasses of water. We must have had 20+ glasses of water at our tables.While we waited to be "let" inside and watched the doorman turn people away, he was telling them that there were three private parties going on and that, basically, the bar was at capacity. When we walked in there was only our party and one other party having the quietest, most tame 30th birthday celebration I've ever seen. The rest of the bar had a sprinkling of patrons here and there. We estimated the bar could have easily fit another 30 patrons at the empty tables and probably still not have been full. And those tables stayed empty all night.The only reason we knew the other party was even "celebrating" anything, if you can call it that, was because they had big "3" and "0" helium balloons at their table. They left WELL before we did, probably out of boredom. We stayed, but only because it was easier than moving everyone to another bar after all the effort to get everyone inside. The bar started playing "My Heart Will Go On" at around 1:30am to encourage everyone to get out. At that point, the place felt like the Titanic. We'd clearly overstayed our UNwelcome and we couldn't pay our tab and get out fast enough!

Really sweet bar featuring a slew of creative drink concoctions. Fair warning though... many of the drinks have a spiced flavor to them... I started the evening off with a mango mixed drink that has some sort of curry spice flavor infused into it... my other friends had various other spices in their drinks as well. Overall, the creative drink menus and wide assortment of cocktails and liquors make this a pretty cool spot in our book!

It's the old Uncle Ming's. I have so many hazy memories here from back in the day. They used to have these grungy looking couches all over the place and getting a drink was a pain because the place used to be crowded with hipsters and young professionals alike. Well the couches are gone, replaced by more respectable looking tables. The funky smelling floor is no longer there.  Most importantly, you don't have to climb over people's shoulders to get a drink anymore cuz they have excellent wait service. The drink menu is extensive. I had a couple of mezcal drinks - the midnight marauder and another one that I asked them to make with lime and pepper. Both were decent. Not top of the line in terms of taste but good enough.It was easy for our group of 8-10 people to have a good time here.  We had called earlier and they said they don't take resos but asked us to come in saying they would figure it out.  At first it was just my friend and I who walked in. As tables opened up, they moved us from a small table of two to a table of 6 and finally the bigger corner table where we all congregated as more of our friends came in.  Without the friendly service, I probably would have gone with 3 stars but like I said, they were helpful throughout and made sure we end up with a large enough space for our group. This is a good cocktail bar that I would happily come back to, especially if I was with big group of people.

Perfection. Got to meet Joaquín Simó when he was creating his awesome cocktails, Tell him what flavors and spirits you like and he will set you up with a great drink just for your palate. He taught me about the different types of chartreuse. They have a lot of different type of chartreuse bottles.
It was a special experience. All of the cocktails were fascinating; together, they were surprisingly diverse. The service was great, friendly, and attentive.

Cute space and had a fun time with an out-of-towner friend, but we went on a Tiki-themed day and most of the drinks on the menu were just wayyyyyy too sweet. I have girly tastebuds when it comes to drink, and even then they were far too sweet for me. I get it, it's Tiki themed...but it would have helped to have a few drier things on the menu, or if they had let us order different drinks :( I feel like I missed out on what this place is really supposed to be like.

Lovely, romantic venue with a vintage feel (aside from the garish green and yellow awning). F and I arrived about half past midnight and saw three people in front of the door speaking with the bouncer. They went up and he checked our IDs and asked we wait two minutes while the party before us gets seated. Then, we went. So happy we didn't have to deal with the hour waits and the "we'll call you" BS of other bars like this. We were given the choice of table or bar; we chose to sit at the bar. Our bartender was friendly and recommended a cocktail for F that was exactly to her liking. I love the layout of the menu; the first page is a grid of all their cocktails denoting whether they are refreshing or spiritous, comforting or adventurous. Genius!I had the Sing For Your Supper, a refreshing & comforting drink with vodka, vanilla passionfruit syrup, aperol and Peychaud's bitters. It was well made and exactly what I was in the mood for. We ordered some beef jerky and cornichons to munch on, no complaints there. Next time, definitely want to try the cheese and meats on the menu. There's also an impressive selection of Chartreuse, if that's your thing (though it's not mine.)Pouring Ribbons is definitely on my list of favorite bars in the city!

Weeknights are perfect for date night, weekend nights fantastic for larger friend groups. Expect knowledgeable bartenders and servers who prioritize the customer. Down to earth atmosphere that accommodates the cocktail savy and dive bar goer just the same. Drinks that will knock your socks off!

The feeling I had in between walking into the bar and being served my drink would have propelled me to give this place 5 stars. However unfortunately, what happened afterwards brings down the rating for me. But I'll start with the positive. The obscured walk-up entrance is really cool and gives this place a vibe of exclusivity. The bouncer was nice and dressed formally, already making this bar seem very bougie. As expected, the crowd was older and more composed. The inside is atmospheric and lit just enough to be romantic and not sketchy. There is a bar area that is louder and an area with cute small tables on the other side which tend to be quieter. Our bartender was fun and helpful in deciding our order. For a bar that has three dollar signs on Yelp, the cocktails aren't terribly expensive at $15. Then the drinks came. I actually ordered a beer because I was in an urgent mood for it, but tried all 6 of my friends' cocktails. All very average despite the cool descriptions that the menu boasted. The beer was a pale ale and was just all right. That was one of two beer selections available. I came back to this bar the next day because I felt that there was a problem with the bill where I got charged for an extra drink (I would've noticed it right away but I was covering for a few people and assumed they were responsible). It was one of those moments when I figured it was too late to argue for it, but I went anyway as it was very close to where I live. Whoever I talked to was quite condescending in describing that the extra charge I was talking about was an included 20% gratuity that of course comes with big groups.
